AU: OH, BC; TERAZAKI, M; NEMOTO, T
AF: OH, BC; TERAZAKI, M; NEMOTO, T
TI: SOME ASPECTS OF THE LIFE-HISTORY OF THE SUB-ARCTIC COPEPOD NEOCALANUS-CRISTATUS (CALANOIDA) IN SAGAMI BAY, CENTRAL JAPAN
AB: A typical subarctic copepod, Neocalanus cristatus, occurred in the mesopelagic layer (500 to 1000 m) in Sagami Bay, central Japan, throughout the year. Specimens were collected from 1982 to 1986. A small number of adult females were distributed from 800 to 900 m only, but no adult males were collected. This species appeared to be abundant in April and August, when intermediate Oyashio water flowed strongly into Sagami Bay. Mean prosome lengths of copepodite stages IV and V and adults were 4.33, 6.8 7 and 6.87 mm, respectively. The condition factor [wet wt/(prosome length) 3 x 100] of copepodite stage V did not vary remarkably, and mean values ranged from 4.7 to 5.0. Prosome length, body weight and condition factor of N. cristatus collected from Sagami Bay were smaller than those of copepods in the northern North Pacific. N. cristatus transported from the north cannot molt to adult stages (except for those originating in mesopelagic waters) due to the adverse environmental conditions in Sagami Bay; instead, they die in the mesopelagic layer and sink to the bathypelagic layer (1000 to 1400 m), close to the bottom. Since nauplii and early copepodite stages did not occur in any season, N. cristatus probably do not reproduce in Sagami Bay.

AU: TAKEUCHI, I; HIRANO, R
AF: TAKEUCHI, I; HIRANO, R
TI: GROWTH AND REPRODUCTION OF CAPRELLA-DANILEVSKII (CRUSTACEA, AMPHIPODA) REARED IN THE LABORATORY
ID: LIFE-HISTORIES; SEX-RATIOS
AB: Caprella danilevskii Czerniavski, an epifaunal amphipod crustacean, was successfully reared for two generations under laboratory conditions. Amphipods were maintained in pairs or fours in a Petri dish. Temperature and photoperiod were maintained at 20-degrees-C, and 14 h light: 10 h dark, respectively. Colonies of the diatom Cylindrotheca closterium (Ehrenberg) Reumann and Lewin were provided as food source. The red alga Gelidium amansii (Lamouroux) Lamouroux was used to provide an attachment substrate for the caprellids. Juveniles that emerged from the brood pouch were described as instar I. Subsequent instars were identified by molts. Juveniles molted successively at 2.5 to 6.5 d intervals. The body length of males at each instar increased exponentially, while that of females followed a sigmoid curve. A different pattern of flagellar segment addition in the antenna I of males and females was revealed. At the age of 20.8 d, females reached instar VII, and produced their first embryos. After 5.1 d, juveniles emerged from the brood pouch. On average, females produced 5.4 clutches successively at 5.0 d intervals. The number of offspring per spawning increased from 6.3 at instar VII to 22.0 at instar XII. The total number of offspring was 69.0 for a female throughout her life span.

AU: SUGISAKI, H; TERAZAKI, M; WADA, E; NEMOTO, T
AF: SUGISAKI, H; TERAZAKI, M; WADA, E; NEMOTO, T
TI: FEEDING-HABITS OF A PELAGIC AMPHIPOD, THEMISTO-JAPONICA
ID: SARGASSO SEA; FOOD WEB; N-15; NITROGEN; RATES; TIME
AB: Vertical distribution, chlorophyll a (chl a) and phaeopigment concentrations in the gut, and natural nitrogen isotope ratio (delta-N-15) were investigated for pelagic amphipods Themisto japonica (Bovallius) collected from the Sea of Japan in July 1987. Differences in diel vertical migration behavior were clearly observed between small and large T.japonica. Many small (< 5 mm body length) amphipods appeared in the phytoplankton-rich shallow layers. Their gut pigment concentrations were higher (mean 0.52 +/- 0.15-mu-g chl a g-1 amphipod) than those of large amphipods (mean 0.33 +/- 0.14-mu-g g-1); this implies that the amphipods fed on a large amount of phytoplankton during the early stage of life. The delta-N-15 values of small amphipods were lower (5.7 to 6.3 parts per thousand) than those of large amphipods (6.8 to 11.7 parts-per thousand), reflecting the lower trophic level of small amphipods compared to large ones. The delta-N-15 values for small amphipods were similar to those of herbivorous zooplankton. The amphipods' feeding behavior thus changes from herbivorous to carnivorous as they grow.

AU: NAKATA, H; KIMURA, S; KISHI, MJ; FUJIWARA, T
AF: NAKATA, H; KIMURA, S; KISHI, MJ; FUJIWARA, T
TI: ENVIRONMENTAL CONSTRAINTS ON THE SAND LANCE POPULATION IN THE EASTERN SETO INLAND SEA
CT: INTERNATIONAL CONF ON THE ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT OF ENCLOSED COASTAL SEAS ( EMECS 90 )
AB: In this paper, focusing on the recruitment processes, we synthesize the results of our recent analytical and numerical studies on the population ecology of the Japanese sand lance in the eastern part of the Seto Inland Sea. Among physical processes, the wind-induced current has a significant effect on the transport and distribution of the larvae. Prey-predator interactions, competion for the specific habitats, and other ecological processes could affect the recruitment. In addition to the year to year variability of the larval hatching and apparent survival rates, some recent trends of the variation in the larval population are also discussed.

AU: FUJIWARA, T; NAKATA, H
AF: FUJIWARA, T; NAKATA, H
TI: FLOW CHARACTERISTICS GOVERNING THE DISTRIBUTION OF WATER AND BOTTOM QUALITY IN A SEMIENCLOSED SEA
CT: INTERNATIONAL CONF ON THE ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT OF ENCLOSED COASTAL SEAS ( EMECS 90 )
AB: Semi-enclosed seas are generally composed of narrow straits and wide basins, forming a strait-basin system. Tidal currents through the strait have a jet-like characteristic. This tidal-jet flows into a stagnant basin and forms a pair of tidal-vortices (vortex dipole). In the strait-basin system, sea area is divided into two regions: well-mixed region around the strait (WM-region), and stagnant and stratified region in the inner part of the basin ( SS-region). The WM-region is the region where highly turbulent water comes from the strait, and the SS-region is the opposite of it. Whether a point is included in the WM-region or the SS-region does not depend on a local parameter, but on the hysteresis of the water. In the WM-region, mass and volume transport are driven by the tidal-vortices. The strait-basin system is characterized by "the high energy tidal-jet flowing from the strait into the stagnant basin with a certain period and intensity". The concept of this system is new and could be interesting in future studies of mass transport in semi-enclosed seas.

AU: KISHI, MJ; IWATA, Y; UCHIYAMA, M
AF: KISHI, MJ; IWATA, Y; UCHIYAMA, M
TI: NUMERICAL-SIMULATION MODEL FOR QUANTITATIVE MANAGEMENT OF MARICULTURE
CT: INTERNATIONAL CONF ON THE ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT OF ENCLOSED COASTAL SEAS ( EMECS 90 )
AB: A numerical model is developed for mariculture management, which consists of four parts: (1)current simulation model which calculates tidal and wind induced currents, (2)COD diffusion model which calculates spatial distribution of COD using simulated current, (3)DO diffusion model which calculates spatial distribution of dissolved oxigen, and (4)accumulation model which calculates distribution of deposits from mariculture of fish. Our model is capable of (1) calculating the detailed spatial distribution of COD and DO by dividing the bay area in to many grid points. (2) taking into consideration the effects of feed and fish in each raft, and the loading of COD from rivers. Using this model, we can assess the influence of the location or the area of the mariculture rafts on the ecological and/or environmental system. It is also of practical use in order to obtain a better distribution of rafts in bay areas, or to calculate the basic data for the renewal of licenses. Application is made to Mikame Bay in Ehime Pref., west part of Japan, as a case study.

AU: COMBRES, Y; LEVAILLANT, C
AF: COMBRES, Y; LEVAILLANT, C
TI: QUANTITATIVE ASSESSMENT OF THE IMPLICATIONS OF STRAIN-INDUCED MICROSTRUCTURAL CHANGES IN SUPERPLASTICITY
SO: METALLURGICAL TRANSACTIONS A-PHYSICAL METALLURGY AND MATERIALS SCIENCE
ID: GRAIN-SIZE DISTRIBUTION; ALLOY; FLOW; DEFORMATION; DIFFUSION; BEHAVIOR; CREEP
AB: During forming at high temperatures and low strain rates, dynamic microstructural changes can be detrimental to the superplastic (SP) properties of metallic alloys. This paper first reviews these possible variations and implications. A classification is set up. Then, starting from the viewpoint that the microstructure is best represented by the grain size distribution, some modeling of the macroscopic stress and strain rate levels is proposed. This hypothesis results in a partition of the grain size distribution by a comparison with a so-called "transition grain size," Dt. Mapping the experimental or theoretical variations of Dt with respect to temperature and strain rate provides a deformation mechanism map. The relative proportion of the grain size classes which fall below Dt, I(sp), can be used to get some quantitative measurement of the SP nature of the material.

TI: MACROPHAGE-MIGRATION INHIBITORY FACTOR (MIF) PRODUCED BY A HUMAN T-CELL HYBRIDOMA CLONE
ID: ACTIVATING FACTOR; MESSENGER-RNA; ANTIBODIES; HYPERSENSITIVITY; ESTABLISHMENT; TRANSLATION; BINDING
AB: A human T cell hybridoma clone, F5, producing high levels of macrophage migration inhibitory factor (MIF) was established by the emetine-actinomycin D selection method. This clone produced two species of MIF which were separated on a Phenyl Sepharose column. We purified MIF-2 (the more hydrophobic species of the two) to homogeneity from the conditioned medium of stimulated F5 cells by a series of steps that included hydrophobic chromatography, ion-exchange chromatography, Ricinus communis lectin affinity chromatography, and high-performance liquid chromatography on anion exchange and reverse-phase columns. Purified MIF was digested with endoproteinase Lys-C and Asp-N. The amino acid sequences of the generated peptides were determined. No sequence similarity with any other protein was found. The molecular weight of MIF-2 was estimated to be 45 kDa from sodium dodecyl sulfate-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis analysis of immunoprecipitates with anti-peptide antibodies. These results show that F5MIF-2 is a novel cytokine.

AF: YAMADA, A; IMANISHI, J; NAKAJIMA, E; NAKAJIMA, K; NAKAJIMA, S
TI: DETECTION OF INFLUENZA-VIRUSES IN THROAT SWAB BY USING POLYMERASE CHAIN-REACTION
ID: DIAGNOSIS; IMMUNOFLUORESCENCE; AMPLIFICATION; INFECTION
AB: An assay protocol based on exploiting the polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for the direct detection of influenza virus in throat swab is described. By use of the mixture of H1 and H3 primers, it was possible to determine the subtype of the influenza A viruses simultaneously. No visible band was detected after PCR of influenza B or A (H2N2) viruses with a pair of H1 or H3 primers. The dilution experiment showed that the influenza viruses, as few as 1.3-6 plaque-forming units, were sufficient for detecting the HA gene by PCR. All throat swab samples from which influenza viruses had been isolated by conventional method were also positively detected by PCR method.

TI: IMMUNE-RESPONSE OF MICE INFECTED WITH RECOMBINANT VACCINIA VIRUSES CARRYING THE HIV GAG GENE
ID: HUMAN-IMMUNODEFICIENCY-VIRUS; TOXIC LYMPHOCYTES-T; GENETICALLY ENGINEERED POXVIRUSES; AIDS VIRUS; INVITRO MUTAGENESIS; BIOLOGICAL-ACTIVITY; SURFACE-ANTIGEN; ENVELOPE GENE; LIVE VACCINES; CELLS
AB: We examined mouse immune response to 4 kinds of recombinant vaccinia viruses carrying the HIV gag gene, including vac-gag/pol, which produces HIV-like particles with processed gag proteins; vac-gag, which also produces HIV-like particles but with unprocessed gag protein; and vac-gag-pol-fuse and vac-es-gag/pol, neither of which produces such particles but releases reverse transcriptase and gag protein, respectively, from infected cells. Although infection of mice with recombinant vaccinia viruses induced production of the anti-p24 antibody in all mice, vac-gag/pol and vac-es-pol induced higher production than the other two recombinants. Increase in [H-3]thymidine uptake by splenic lymphocytes following p24 antigen stimulation was most evident in mice infected with vac-gag/pol. Thus, the highest immune reaction, both humoral and cellular, was elicited by vac-gag/pol, indicating that among those tested, this recombinant vaccinia virus is the best candidate for a vaccine that induces anti-HIV gag immunity.

AU: KOBAYASHI, Y; YOSHIMATSU, K; OSAWA, T
AF: KOBAYASHI, Y; YOSHIMATSU, K; OSAWA, T
TI: NATURAL-KILLER (NK) CELL ACTIVATING FACTOR PRODUCED BY A HUMAN T-CELL HYBRIDOMA
ID: INTERLEUKIN-2; PURIFICATION; LYMPHOCYTES; INTERFERON
AB: A human T-cell hybridoma (KC8-1.10), whose culture supernatant augments peripheral blood lymphocytes (PBL)-mediated spontaneous cytotoxicity against K562 cells, was established. This activity [natural killer (NK) cell activating activity] appears to be not due to interferon-gamma (IFN-gamma) and interleukin-2 (IL-2) for the following reasons: 1) KC8-1.10 produced negligible or small amounts of IFNs and IL-2. 2) The NK cell activating activity in the KC8-1.10 culture supernatant was not neutralized by anti-IFN-gamma antiserum and stable even after pH 2 treatment for 24 hr, which is known to destroy IFN-gamma activity. 3) IL-2-dependent cell line absorbed IL-2 more efficiently than it absorbed the NK cell activating activity, and the latter activity was not retained by Blue Sepharose column in contrast with IL-2. The NK cell activating factor in the KC8-1.10 culture supernatant appears to be a glycoprotein, because the activity was abolished with pronase treatment or with boiling for 5 min and because the activity was retained by concanavalin A- and Pisum sativum agglutinin-agarose. Finally it was found that the NK cell activating activity requires Leu 11b+ cells to exert its effect.

AU: SAITO, S; KAWAKITA, M
AF: SAITO, S; KAWAKITA, M
TI: INHIBITOR OF INTERFERON-INDUCED DOUBLE-STRANDED RNA-DEPENDENT PROTEIN-KINASE AND ITS RELEVANCE TO ALTERATION OF CELLULAR PROTEIN-KINASE ACTIVITY LEVEL IN RESPONSE TO EXTERNAL STIMULI
ID: PURIFICATION; VIRUS
AB: In FL cells, interferon (IFN)-induced dsRNA-dependent protein kinase (PK-I) was found to be present in a form complexed with a potent inhibitor of its dsRNA-dependent activation. The inhibitor was readily dissociated from PK-I by DEAE-cellulose chromatography to yield a dsRNA-responsive PK-I. The inhibitor was also dissociated easily from PK-I by gel filtration through Sephacryl S-200. The apparent molecular mass of the inhibitor as estimated by gel filtration was more than 160 kilodaltons. Activity of the inhibitor was decreased on IFN treatment for 8.5 hr or on Sindbis virus infection with concomitant increase in the amount of dsRNA-activatable form of PK-I. This result implies that the inhibitor may be one of the regulatory factors of cellular PK-I activity. Longer IFN treatment (24 hr) led to recovery of the inhibitor activity, but it was overridden by an extensive net synthesis of the PK-I protein.

AU: SHIMIZU, M; STANLEY, CJ; CRIDDLE, AJ; KATO, A; MATSUBARA, S
AF: SHIMIZU, M; STANLEY, CJ; CRIDDLE, AJ; KATO, A; MATSUBARA, S
TI: NEW COMPOSITIONAL AND OPTICAL-DATA FOR ANTIMONIAN AND BISMUTHIAN VARIETIES OF HEMUSITE FROM JAPAN
ID: ARIZONA; BISBEE
AB: New compositional and optical data are reported for antimonian and antimonian-bismuthian varieties of hemusite from epithermal Au-Ag-Cu deposits in Japan. The empirical formula for the antimonian variety, from the Iriki mine is: (Cu5.83Fe0.14Ag0.01)SIGMA-5.98Mo1.03(Sn0.54Sb0.41Te0.03Bi0.02)SIGMA-1.00(S7.85Se0.15)SIGMA-8.00, and that of the Sb-Bi variety from the Kawazu mine is: (Cu5.84Fe0.14Ag0.01)SIGMA-5.99Mo1.03(Sn0.82Sb0.11Bi0.10Te0.04)SIGMA-1.07(S7.80Se0.12)SIGMA-7.92. The theoretical formula of hemusite is Cu+4Cu2+2Mo4+Sn4+S8, whilst the most probable formula of the Iriki hemusite is Cu+4.5Cu2+1.5Mo4+Sn4+0.5Sb5+0.5S8, with Sb5+ substituting for Sn4+ and forming (SbS4)3- tetrahedra as might be expected, given that the metal to sulphur ratio is 1, and given the sphalerite-like structure of the mineral. However Bi3+ cannot be so accommodated, resulting in a deficiency in (S + Se) for Kawazu hemusite. Reflectance spectra for both are compared with those of the tungsten analogue (compositional) of hemusite, kiddcreekite. The relationship between hemusite sensu stricto and these newly reported varieties is discussed in terms of simple and coupled chemical substitutions, and inferences are drawn on the valency of Sb, Bi, Mo and Cu in the hemusite structure.

TI: DEGRADATION OF A QUINONE-TYPE MODEL-COMPOUND BY PHANEROCHAETE-CHRYSOSPORIUM AND ITS LIGNIN PEROXIDASE
DE: PHANEROCHAETE-CHRYSOSPORIUM; LIGNIN PEROXIDASE; QUINONE MODEL-COMPOUND; VERATRYL ALCOHOL
ID: HYDROGEN-PEROXIDE; VERATRYL ALCOHOL; BASIDIOMYCETE; INVOLVEMENT; OXIDATION; OXYGEN; SYSTEM
AB: A quinone type model compound, 2-hydroxy-1,4-naphthoquinone (HNQ), was degraded completely by Phanerochaete chrysosporium Burds. to yield phthalic acid. HNQ was degraded to some unknown products by a system consisting of isolated lignin peroxidase, hydrogen peroxide, and veratryl alcohol, whereas no reaction was observed without veratryl alcohol. Spectral study of this reaction system indicates that the presence of HNQ inhibits the oxidation of veratryl alcohol by lignin peroxidase and thus, the formation of veratraldehyde starts only after the degradation of HNQ. The degradation rate of HNQ was greatly dependent on the concentration of veratryl alcohol.

AU: LEE, WH; OKANO, T; OHTA, M
AF: LEE, WH; OKANO, T; OHTA, M
TI: MOISTURE TRANSMISSION IN WOOD - MOISTURE TRANSFER AND VELOCITY OF MOISTURE TRANSMISSION IN A STEADY-STATE
DE: MOISTURE TRANSMISSION; VAPOR PERMEABILITY; VAPOR-TRANSMISSION RESISTANCE; DIFFUSION COEFFICIENT; MOISTURE TRANSFER
AB: In general, the behavior of moisture transmission is estimated by vapor permeability or vapor-transmission resistance, but its values obtained by experiments do not have great adaptability for practical situations because of changes in the experimental conditions. This fact is why only theoretical discussions have advanced. Thus, the fundamental study of the moisture-transmission phenomenon has been treated lightly. Here, as the first step toward basic research of moisture transmission, the amount of moisture transmission and the moisture distribution in specimens were investigated. The experiment was conducted in a steady state, and the moisture distribution was measured by slicing and weighing the specimens. From the examination of the vapor-transmission resistance, the phenomenon of moisture transmission was dealt with divide the moisture transfer on the wood surface and moisture diffusion in the wood. The following conclusions were obtained: 1) The phenomenon of moisture transmission should be approached by its division into moisture transfer on the wood surface and moisture diffusion in the wood because the positive values of vapor-transmission resistance exist in the extrapolation of thickness 0 mm. 2) The distribution of moisture in wood can be illustrated by two straight lines intersecting at the point of nine percent moisture content: namely, diffusion coefficients have two constant values at moisture contents below and above nine percent. The shape of the distribution curve of moisture content is similar irrespective of the wood thickness. 3) The amount of moisture movement is determined by the moisture gradient in wood. 4) Coefficients of the moisture transfer depend on the thickness of the specimens. The reason for this phenomenon is not clear yet.
C1: UNIV TOKYO, FAC AGR, TOKYO 113, JAPAN
CR: Choong E. AU: NAKAJIMA, S; ARIMA, T; NAKAMURA, N; ICHIKAWA, J
AF: NAKAJIMA, S; ARIMA, T; NAKAMURA, N; ICHIKAWA, J
TI: VIBRATING PROPERTIES OF A WOODEN STRUCTURE WITH AN OCTAGONAL PLANE
DE: FULLSCALE TEST; CONVENTIONAL HOUSE; OCTAGONAL PLANE; VIBRATION PROPERTIES; NATURAL FREQUENCY
AB: A full-scale conventional house with an octagonal plane (eight-sided house) was tested under dynamic loads to clarify its vibration properties. The effects of the walls, arranged 45-degrees to the main axis, on the vibration properties of the structure were examined and are discussed. The results are summarized as follows: (1) A structure with an octagonal plane generally had two main axis which meet at right angles, and it is displaced in two directions when it is vibrated. (2) As the stiffness of the walls arranged 45-degrees to the main axis increased, the natural frequency of the structure became greater. (3) Compared with the walls parallel to the main axis, the walls arranged 45-degrees to the main axis had half as large resistance to the dynamic loads parallel to the main axis. This experimental fact agreed with already-known theory. (4) The damping ratio of the structure increased as the quantity of braces and sheathing increased. Regarding this upward tendency of the damping constant, the walls arranged 45-degrees to the main axis contributed to it almost equally with that of the walls parallel to the main axis.

AU: LEE, WH; OKANO, T; OHTA, M
AF: LEE, WH; OKANO, T; OHTA, M
TI: MOISTURE TRANSMISSION IN WOOD II - THE AMOUNTS OF MOISTURE TRANSMISSION CALCULATED BY DIFFUSION-COEFFICIENTS OF MOISTURE TRANSFER
DE: MOISTURE TRANSMISSION; MOISTURE DIFFUSION COEFFICIENT; MOISTURE TRANSFER COEFFICIENT
AB: The amount of moisture transmitted and the distribution of the moisture content under various humidity conditions were measured for three kinds of softwoods (tangential and radial directions) and three kinds of hardwoods (tangential direction). The amount of moisture transmitted in wood was calculated using moisture diffusion coefficients and coefficients of moisture transfer, and these were compared with experimental values. The following results were obtained. 1) When the moisture content on one side of the wood was less than 9 percent and the other side was more than 9 percent, the distribution of the moisture content could be illustrated by two straight lines intersecting at 9 percent for the moisture content. On the other hand, when the moisture contents on both sides were more than 9 percent, the distribution of the moisture content could be illustrated by one straight line. 2) The moisture diffusion coefficients and the coefficients of moisture transfer had no relationship to any experimental conditions and specific gravities of wood, and the values of softwoods were different from those of hardwoods. 3) The amount of moisture transmission calculated with four constant values had a good tendency to agree with the experimental values (significant level = 5%, mean square error (MSE) = 1.01 x 10(-6)). 4) It is suggested that the amount of moisture transmitted could be predicted well with the moisture diffusion coefficient and the coefficient of the moisture transfer.

AU: UCHISAKO, T; SUGIYAMA, H; ANDO, N; ARIMA, T; HIRANO, S; NAKAMURA, N
AF: UCHISAKO, T; SUGIYAMA, H; ANDO, N; ARIMA, T; HIRANO, S; NAKAMURA, N
TI: FULL-SCALE LATERAL LOADING TESTS OF A JAPANESE CONVENTIONAL WOOD FRAME HOUSE-I
DE: FULL-SCALE HOUSE; RACKING STIFFNESS; LET-IN BRACING; CONSTRUCTION STAGE
AB: A series of lateral-loading tests was conducted on a full-scale two-story Japanese conventional wood-frame house. That is, the local loadings, in which a lateral load was applied to the top of the first story of each frame, at various construction stages, during which the conditions of installation of structural elements such as let-in bracings and exterior siding in the first story were changed, to allow an investigation of the influences of those elements on the racking resistance of the test house. 1) From the value of a load which caused a horizontal deflection of 3 mm at the top of a first story loaded frame (This load is called "3 mm-load" hereinafter), (that is, a distortion angle of about a 1/1000 radian) in the construction stages with solely let-in bracings, the following results were observed: 1. The value of a 3 mm-load on a frame, to which the first floors are connected on a both sides, was greater than that of a frame connected to the first floor on one side of the frame. 2. The area of the floor opening does not have much effect on the stiffness of the loaded frames. 3. The value of a 3 mm-load was decreased by the repetition of loading. 2) From the value of a 3 mm-load in the construction stages in which exterior siding was fastened to let-in bracings and exterior siding was fastened to the wall parts above and below windows and door openings, it was found that: 1. The values of 3 mm-loads of the exterior frames were increased much by fastening exterior siding to parts of let-in bracings and, on the other hand, those of interior frames also were increased at the same time, although the racking stiffnesses of both were not increased. 2. The values of 3 mm-loads of the frames parallel to the loading direction were increased slightly by fastening exterior siding to the frames perpendicular to the loading directions. 3. The values of 3 mm-loads of all frames were increased much by fastening exterior siding to the wall parts above and below windows and door openings. 4. The value of a 3 mm-load of a frame having large racking stiffness was greater than those of frames that had smaller stiffnesses. When the racking stiffnesses of frames are the same, the value of a 3 mm-load for a frame connected to the first floor on both sides is larger than that for a frame connected to the first floor on one side.

TI: RHEOLOGICAL STUDY ON ADHESIVE STRENGTH-I - DEPENDENCE OF ADHESIVE STRENGTH OF POLY (VINYL-ACETATE) ON TEMPERATURE AND RATE OF DEFORMATION
DE: PVAC ADHESIVES; RHEOLOGY; ADHESIVE SHEAR STRENGTH; ADHESIVE TENSILE STRENGTH; PEEL STRENGTH
AB: Adhesive shear strength, adhesive tensile strength, and peel strength of three poly (vinyl acetate) (PVAc)-based adhesives were measured as a function of both temperature and rate of deformation. Smooth master curves were obtained by applying the time (rate)-temperature superposition principle to the experimental data. Every master curve had a peak at some rate of deformation, and the peak shifted toward the lower rate side as the temperature of the dynamic mechanical absorption peak of the adhesive became higher, or the average relaxation time of the adhesive became longer. For every adhesive under study, adhesive shear strength, adhesive tensile strength, and peel strength became maximum at diffement rates of deformation, that is, a peak was found at the highest rate for adhesive shear strength, and at lowest rate for peel strength. Adhesive tensile strength became maximum at a slightly lower rate than adhesive shear strength did. Some of the general features of these observations can be qualitatively accounted for by the simplified theory described previously 1).

TI: RHEOLOGICAL STUDY ON ADHESIVE STRENGTH-II - RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN FRACTURE-TOUGHNESS AND ADHESIVE STRENGTH OF ADHESION SYSTEMS BONDED WITH POLYVINYL ACETATE OR EPOXY-RESIN
DE: ADHESIVE SHEAR STRENGTH; ADHESIVE TENSILE STRENGTH; FRACTURE TOUGHNESS; DOUBLE TORSION METHOD; FINITE ELEMENT METHOD
AB: Adhesive shear strength, adhesive tensile strength, and fracture toughness, G1c by the double torsion method of adhesion system bonded with two Polyvinyl acetate (PVAc)-based adhesives or epoxy resin were measured over a wide temperature range, and stress distributions in two types of test specimens were calculated according to the finite element method. In the temperature range where the adhesives are glassy, both adhesive strengths and G1c decreased as temperature decreased. This means that in this temperature range stress concentrates at the end corners of the glue-line even in the usual adhesion tests, and then micro-cracks are initiated in the parts which lead to the fracture of the whole adhesion system. It was shown by the stress analysis that the stress concentrates in the element at the edge of the glue layer which is nearest to the interface. In conclusion, it can be assumed that a fracture of the adhesion system occurs when the stress component, sigma-Y, which is perpendicular to the glue-line at the edge of the glue layer, reaches a critical value, sigma-Yc, in order to explain the experimental fact that adhesive tensile strengths are lower than adhesive shear strengths and that adhesive strengths become lower as the test temperature decreases when the adhesives are glassy.

AU: ISOGAI, A; USUDA, M

TI: PREPARATION OF LOW-MOLECULAR-WEIGHT CELLULOSES USING PHOSPHORIC-ACID
DE: CELLULOSE; REGENERATION; HYDROLYSIS; PHOSPHORIC ACID; DEGREE OF POLYMERIZATION
ID: CELLO-OLIGOSACCHARIDES; C-13-NMR SPECTRA; POLYMORPHS
AB: Two kinds of low-molecular weight regenerated celluloses, A and B, which were prepared using phosphoric acid as a cellulose solvent of Whatman CF-11 and a media for homogeneous acid hydrolysis, were characterized in terms of yields, degrees of polymerization (DP), solid-state structures, and others. The regenerated cellulose A, which was obtained as a precipitate in the yield of about 40% by pouring the cellulose solution into water after leaving the solution standing for 6 weeks, had DP(n) and DP(w)/DP(n) values of 15 and 1.15, respectively. The regenerated cellulose B, which was obtained as a precipitate in the yield of about 15% by pouring the resulting filtrate into methanol, had DP(n) and DP(w)/DP(n) values of 7 and 1.07, respectively. The cellulose B had a highly crystalline structure, and was soluble in dimethylsulfoxide. Thus, low-molecular weight cellulose samples with almost a monodispersion of their molecular weight distributions can be obtained in greater yields using phosphoric acid rather than the conventional cello-oligosaccharides.

TI: PROPERTIES OF BOARDS MADE FROM ZEPHYR PARTICLES .1. EFFECTS OF ZEPHYR PARTICLE LENGTH AND ORDINARY CHIP ADMIXTURE ON THE BENDING PROPERTIES OF BOARDS
DE: ZEPHYR; CRUSHING WITH ROLLERS; MIXING RATIO; PARTICLE LENGTH; BENDING PROPERTIES
ID: CONTINUOUS FIBERS; NETWORK; WOOD
AB: This study was designed to utilize 'Zephyr' as the basic element in the production of particleboard. This first part of the study focused on the determination and evaluation of the effects of 'Zephyr' particle length and ordinary chip mixing ratio on the bending properties (modulus of rupture, MOR and modulus of elasticity, MOE) of the boards. Results are summarized as follows: 1) Boards made of 40 mm long 'Zephyr' particles yield larger MOR and MOE than those with 20 mm long particles. Beyond a length of 40 mm, that is, 60 or 80 mm, there were only slight differences in these properties. 2) At the same board density, boards made from the combination of 'Zephyr' particles and ordinary chips had better bending properties than boards in pure form (pure ordinary chips or pure 'Zephyr' particles). As in the case when the MOR and MOE of the boards were plotted as functions of chip mixing ratio, maximum curves were obtained. 3) Increasing the amount of ordinary chips (or 'Zephyr' particles) added to 'Zephyr' particles (or ordinary chips) improved the bending properties of the boards due to increased board density. Moreover, beyond a board density of 0.56 g/cm3, results indicated the mixing effects on these properties.

AU: YOSHIHARA, H; OHTA, M
AF: YOSHIHARA, H; OHTA, M
TI: A FAILURE CRITERION WHICH ENABLES THE PREDICTION OF THE FAILING DIRECTION FOR ORTHOTROPIC MATERIALS
DE: FAILURE CRITERION; TENSILE STRENGTH; FAILING DIRECTION; OFF-AXIS SPECIMENS; ORTHOTROPIC MATERIALS
AB: In this report, we propose a failure criterion for orthotropic materials which enables the prediction of the failing angle, that is, the angle between the failure surface and the grain. The validity of this criterion was examined by uniaxial tension tests with off-axis specimens of sitka spruce (Picea sitchensis Carr.) and katsura (Cercidiphyllum japonicum Sieb. and Zucc.). Our criterion gave a good approximation for the relationship between the grain angle and the corresponding tensile strength. The failing angle for spruce was almost zero when the grain angle was more than ten degrees, whereas that of katsura had some values. Our criterion approximately explained these tendencies, but the prediction was larger than the experimental data in the grain-angle range where the shear strength, S, was the dominant strength component (nearly ten degrees for spruce and fifteen degrees for katsura) because of the large value of shear strength obtained by torsion tests. The failure criterion proposed in this report did not agree completely with the experimental results, but we think that it would be useful to know the failing direction as well as the stress conditions at the time of occurrence of failure.

AU: SUGIYAMA, H; UCHISAKO, T
AF: SUGIYAMA, H; UCHISAKO, T
TI: INPLANE STIFFNESS OF A PLYWOOD-SHEATHED WOODEN FLOOR OBSERVED FROM THE TEST OF A FULL-SCALE HOUSE
DE: FULL-SCALE HOUSE TEST; JAPANESE CONVENTIONAL CONSTRUCTION; PLYWOOD-SHEATHED FLOOR; INPLANE SHEAR STIFFNESS
AB: In this study, the behavior of an in-plane deformation of a wooden floor of Japanese conventional wooden construction was analysed using the test results of a full-scale two-story wooden house, and furthermore, the in-plane shear stiffness of the floor was calculated. In the full-scale test, a horizontal concentrated force was applied, in sequence, to the top of a shear wall line of the lower-story in which four shear wall-lines parallel to the horizontal force were arranged. This procedure was repeated during the four construction stages (Table 1). The wooden floor of the upper story, which was 7.28 m in the horizontal-force direction and 10.01 m in length, was framed with joists, 4.5 x 9 cm in cross-section which were spaced on 22.75 cm centers, and Lauan (Shorea sp.) plywood sheets, 12 mm-thick, as large as 3 x 6 feet were fastened onto the joists by N -45 nails spaced 15 cm apart. The in-plane deformation of the floor was analysed on the basis of the assumption that in-plane deformation is the shear deformation resulting from a shearing force. In other words, the effect of deformation due to bending was neglected in the analysis of in-plane deformation. The value of in-plane shear stiffness was 2.3-4 x 10(5) (average 3.2 x 10(5))kgf/m/rad. (kgf per linear meter in the direction of the horizontal force) for the range of shear deformation angles (or shearing strains) of less than 1/1000, and about 1.7 x 10(5) kgf/m/rad. for 1/1000-1/500 radians.

AU: TOKUDA, M; UCHISAKO, T
AF: TOKUDA, M; UCHISAKO, T
TI: RACKING STRENGTH OF JAPANESE CONVENTIONAL PANELS SHEATHED LATERALLY WITH THINNED SUGI LOGS
DE: THINNED-SUGI LOGS; RACKING TEST; DOWEL REINFORCED PANEL; GLUED PANEL; STEEL BRACED PANEL
AB: Racking tests of panels made of logs from sugi (Cryptomeria japonica D. Don) were conducted (Figs. 1 and 2). Three methods to prevent slipping between the logs were employed: glued, dowel jointed and steel braced panels. There were seven panels. No. 1 had no reinforcement between the logs. The logs of No. 2 were glued together fully, and those of No. 3 partially. No. 4 through No. 6 panels were reinforced with hardwood dowels. No. 7 panel was reinforced with a steel brace. The following results were obtained. 1) The glued panels made of logs from sugi thinnings were the strongest, followed by the steel braced panel. The weakest were the dowel-jointed panels. 2) The panel strength ratio of the glued panels, the ratio of the load per one meter at 1/20 rad. shear deformation divided by 130 kgf, was more than 3. Because slightly poor gluing had no effects on the rigidity of the panels, gluing on site is possible. However, because glued panels are extremely rigid, attention to stress concentration is necessary. 3) The panel strength ratio of steel-braced panel was about 2.5, and the manufacture of it was easier than any other panel. 4) The panel strength ratios of the dowel jointed panels, which depend on the fitness of the dowel joints, were about 2. 5) Shear deformation of the panels were nearly equal to the summation of the slip between the logs. In particular, in the dowel-jointed panels, shear deformation could be estimated by the double shear test results of the dowel joints.

AU: MAEDA, S; OKANO, T; OHTA, M
AF: MAEDA, S; OKANO, T; OHTA, M
TI: EFFECTS OF DRYING RESTRAINT, DENSITY, AND FIBER ORIENTATION ON YOUNG MODULI OF LINERBOARDS AND MEDIA
DE: YOUNG MODULUS; DRYING RESTRAINT; DENSITY; FIBER ORIENTATION; LINERBOARD
AB: Young's moduli of commercial linerboards of four groups and media were measured. The degrees of Young's moduli almost corresponded with the classification based on the Japan Industrial Standard and grades of raw fibers. Drying restraint was released by a water immersion-free drying treatment (WF-treatment). Young's moduli decreases and residual dimensional changes, resulting from the WF-treatment, were greater in the cross machine-direction than in the machine direction, and were remarkable in the media. However, specific Young's modulus, that is, Young's modulus relating to the apparent sheet density, after the WF-treatment showed a slight difference between the linerboards and the media. The effect of fiber orientation was eliminated by using the fiber orientation function on the assumption that linerboards and media are composite materials of anisotropic lamellae and isotropic substances, and Young's moduli of these components was induced. Using these values, Young's moduli of model linerboards and media with uniaxial fiber orientations, were calculated. As a result, the Young's moduli had magnifications classified into three groups: K, J and W, and C and M, which is similar to that of the Young's moduli of the samples before removing the effects of drying restraint, density, and fiber orientation. It indicates that Young's moduli of linerboards and media are dominated mainly by Young's moduli of raw materials and are not greatly affected by these factors.

AU: KIM, NH; SUGIYAMA, J; OKANO, T
AF: KIM, NH; SUGIYAMA, J; OKANO, T
TI: X-RAY AND ELECTRON-DIFFRACTION STUDY OF NA-CELLULOSE-I THE EFFECT OF WASHING TEMPERATURE ON THE STRUCTURE OF NA-CELLULOSE-I
DE: CELLULOSE-I; MERCERIZATION; NA-CELLULOSE-I; NA-CELLULOSE-IV; RAMIE
ID: MERCERIZATION; MECHANISM
AB: The effect of temperature in washing Na-cellulose I was studied by X-ray and electron diffraction methods. When Na-cellulose I was washed with water at high-temperatures, X-ray diffraction analyses of samples revealed a partial reconversion into cellulose I. The greater the washing temperature, the more cellulose I was regenerated from Na-cellulose I(I). In fact, when washed at 100-degrees-C, Na-cellulose I(I) was transformed directly into a mixture of celluloses I and II, and Na-cellulose I(II) was transformed to only cellulose II. On the other hand, when Na-cellulose I was washed with water at 0-degrees-C, the complete formation of Na-cellulose IV resulted, and it was converted perfectly into cellulose II after drying. When Na-cellulose I(I) was washed at 20-degrees-C to 80-degrees-C, the diagram showed a mixture of celluloses I and II and Na-cellulose IV, while that of Na-cellulose I(II) gave cellulose II and Na-cellulose IV. However, the recovery of cellulose I from Na-cellulose I(I) decreased by aging it in an alkali solution. The electron diffraction diagrams of regenerated cellulose at 60-degrees-C and 100-degrees-C showed cellulose I in both the inner and the outer layers, and the ratio of cellulose I was larger in the inner layer. When Na-cellulose I was washed at 100-degrees-C, cellulose I was regenerated more than that at 60-degrees-C. From the above results, it was considered that the metastable Na-cellulose I caused by incomplete swelling was present in the inner layer and was transformed into Na-cellulose IV in low-temperature washing (hydration), whereas it was reconverted to cellulose I in high-temperature washing (dehydration). It was concluded that complete Na-cellulose I cannot be reconverted to cellulose I, and the conversion of a parallel to an antiparallel chain packing or a bent to a bent-twisted chain conformation could occur during alkaline swelling.

AU: MAEDA, S; OKANO, T; OHTA, M
AF: MAEDA, S; OKANO, T; OHTA, M
TI: EFFECTS OF DRYING RESTRAINT AND FIBER ORIENTATION ON SHRINKAGE RATE OF LINERBOARDS AND CORRUGATING MEDIA
DE: CONTAINER BOARDS; DRYING STRAIN; FIBER ORIENTATION; SHRINKAGE RATE
AB: Shrinkage rates of K-liner (K), jute liner (J), white liner (W), C-liner (C), and corrugating medium (M) were measured and the effects of drying restraint and fiber orientation on shrinkage rates were studied. The effects of drying restraint were removed by a water-immersion free-drying treatment (WF-treatment). Drying strain, that is, the effects of drying restraint, were greater in the machine direction (MD) than in the cross-machine direction (CD) for all samples. This indicated that the drawing force had a greater effect on shrinkage rates than did the friction force between paper webs and canvas/dryer surfaces. The effects of fiber orientation were removed by using the fiber-orientation function obtained through X-ray diffraction, and shrinkage rates of model container boards with uniaxial fiber orientations were deduced. The shrinkage rates of models were smaller than those after WF-treatments in the MD; the scattering of the shrinkage rates increased in the CD. These results show that the magnitude and scattering of shrinkage rates of raw materials decrease as drying restraint and fiber-orientation distribution are applied in the production process, and that the raw materials are processed into products which have more stabilized shrinkage rates.

AU: SUEMATSU, A; OKUMA, M
AF: SUEMATSU, A; OKUMA, M
TI: MECHANISM OF LOW-DENSITY PARTICLEBOARD FORMATION .3. INTERNAL-BOND STRENGTH AND INTERLAMINAR-SHEAR STRENGTH OF LOW-DENSITY PARTICLEBOARD
DE: LOW-DENSITY PARTICLEBOARD; INTERLAMINAR-SHEAR STRENGTH; INTERNAL-BOND STRENGTH; SPRING BACK
AB: Homogeneous low-density particleboards were produced using two species and two adhesives, a phenolic resin (PF) and an isocyanate compound resin (IC). Resin content level was 10% based on dry-wood weight. Overall board thickness was 15 mm with target densities from 0.30-0.60 g/cm3. The total press-times were 10 minutes for PF and 5 minutes for IC at a 160-degrees-C platen temperature in a "one-step" pressing process. The effects of resin types, species, and board densities on interlaminar-shear strength (IS) and the internal-bond strength (IB) of the face-layers and the center-core, and the reductions of IS and IB after vaccum-water-soaking (24 hr) and drying (40-degrees-C, 48 hr) treatments were investigated. Results were as follows: 1) IS and IB of the face-layers were greater than that of the center-core in spite of the same densities in the broken parts. It is assumed that particles of the face-layers could stick to each other better than those of the center-core because of the differences in quality and quantity of particle binding-points. 2) The maximum pressure during the hot pressing increased linearly with increases in the compaction ratio, and was dependent on particle species. It is necessary to apply a pressure of more than 10 kgf/cm2 to obtain boards having the IB of more than 2 kgf/cm2. PF boards with densities of 0.50 g/cm3 had the IB of more than 5 kgf/cm2, which indicates the possibility of using PF as a binder for low-density particleboard. 3) A large correlation was observed between IS and IB for face-layers and the center-core. The ratio between strength values (IS/IB; 3.83 in the center-core) indicated the characteristic property of particleboards. 4) Retentions of IS and IB after vaccum-water-soaking-drying treatments had no effects from species, resin types, and differences of face-layers and center-core. It was estimated that retentions after treatments were 75% of those before treatments. However, hinoki (Chamaecyparis obtusa (S. and Z.) Endl.) PF boards had greater spring back than those of buna (Fagus crenata Bl.) IC boards. Hinoki PF boards maintained about the same percent retentions of IS and IB. Consequently, it can be considered that there is no effect of spring back on IS and IB for low-density particleboards.

TI: PREPARATION OF CELLULOSE CINNAMATE AND DISTRIBUTION OF CINNAMOYL GROUPS
DE: CINNAMOYLATION; LITHIUM CHLORIDE-DIMETHYLACETAMIDE; DISTRIBUTION; DEGREE OF SUBSTITUTION; CELLULOSE DERIVATIVE
AB: Cinnamates of cellulose and cellulose derivatives were prepared by three methods: 1) a heterogeneous method in which pyridine was used as both a medium and a base, 2) the Schotten-Baumann method in which cellulosic samples were dissolved in an aqueous medium, and 3) a homogeneous method in which a nonaqueous cellulose solvent (lithium chloride-dimethylacetamide) was used as a medium. It took 30 min at 60-degrees-C to obtain completely cinnamoylated products by the third method. Furthermore, cinnamoylation of cellulose by this method was found to occur at C6-OH selectively, when degrees of substitution were kept less than one using a weak base such as pyridine or N,N-dimethylaniline.

AU: SHIDA, S
AF: SHIDA, S
TI: EQUILIBRIUM MOISTURE-CONTENT OF SOME WOOD-BASED MATERIALS
DE: WOOD-BASED MATERIAL; EQUILIBRIUM MOISTURE CONTENT; ADSORPTION; ADSORPTION ISOTHERM; HAILWOOD-HORROBIN MODEL
AB: This paper reports on the equilibrium moisture content (EMC) of some wood-based materials. EMCs were measured under the moisture adsorption course at 60-degrees-C, and were compared with those of solid woods. Constant M in equation 1 was determined from EMC data by fitting it to Hailwood-Horrobin's model.1) The relationships between the EMCs of wood-based materials and constant M are discussed. The following results were obtained: 1) The EMCs of hardboard (HB) and sheating insulation board (SB) were 20-30% less in comparison with the EMCs of solid wood. The EMC of particleboard (PB) was 0-17% greater in comparison with that of solid wood in a high relative humidity (R.H.) range. Plywood (PW) had almost the same EMC or was 10% less than that of solid wood. The EMC of PW increased according to the lamination layer being increased. 2) Constant M in equation 1 is possibly an index of the adsoption ability of materials, and it means the mass of polymer substance associated with one mole of water as a hydrate. A negative correlation was recognized between the M value and the EMC. The order of the M value is solid wood < PW < PB < HB < SB. PB bonded with phenolic-resin adhesive has a large EMC in a high R.H. range in spite of having a large M value.

AU: SHIDA, S; SHIBUSAWA, T; HUKUSHIMA, Y
AF: SHIDA, S; SHIBUSAWA, T; HUKUSHIMA, Y
TI: UTILIZATION AND EVALUATION OF EXTERIOR WOOD .2. SENSORY WARMTH OF THE DECK MATERIALS
DE: SENSORY WARMTH; PAIRED COMPARISONS METHOD; EXTERIOR WOOD; DECKS; COMPARATIVE JUDGMENT LOW
AB: The sensory warmths of deck materials were estimated by the method of paired comparisons at 60-degrees-C. We considered the relationships between the sensory warmths and the thermal conductivities, surface temperatures, and the specific gravities of deck members. The results were as follows; (1) Foamed-plastics and bongosshi (Lophia alata Banks ex Gartner) felt quite hot; teak (Tectona grandis L.) felt a slightly hot; western hemlock (Tsuga heterophylla ((Raf.)) Sarg.), Japanese cypress (Chamaecyparis obtusa ((S. and Z.) Endl.) and redwood (Sequoia Sempervirens ((D. Don)) Endl.) felt moderate; Japanese cedar (Cryptmeria japonica D. Don) and surface-grooved western hemlock felt slightly cold (Fig. 2). (2) A positive correlation was recognized between specific gravity and the sensory warmth. Foamed-plastics felt very hot in spite of having comparatively small specific gravities (Fig. 4). (3) A positive correlation also was recognized between the thermal conductivity and the sensory warmth, but the foamed-plastics and the surface-grooved western hemlock had results different from the other materials. This means that the sensory warmth in effected by the surface conditions of materials (Fig. 3). (4) A positive correlation also was recognized between the surface temperature and sensory warmth (Fig. 5). (5) Surface temperature seemed to be a more suitable indicator of sensory warmth than the other physical factors, such as thermal conductivity and specific gravity.

AB: This paper describes the relationships between the fracture toughness and the Single edge notched specimens of the tangential-radial (TR) crack propagation system of sugi (Cryptomeria japonica D. Don) were employed in the experiment. Tension tests of these specimens were made under AE monitoring. The results are summerized as follows: 1) The critical stress intensity factor (K(IC)) values, which were calculated from the load at crack initiation, varied according to the location of the crack tip in a single annual-ring and the direction of crack propagation: namely, from pith to bark or from bark to pith. When the crack tip was located in the earlywood, the K(IC) value increased with decreasing distance between the crack tip and the latewood located forward of the tip. When the crack tip was located in the latewood, its value was relatively small. 2) In the AE amplitude distribution up to the load at crack initiation, two population peaks were observed at the amplitudes of 45 dB and 70 dB. This suggests that there are two microscopic fracture types with different energy levels. There was a positive correlation between the K(IC) value and the m-value, which represents the quantitative value of the AE amplitude distribution. Therefore, it was found that the AE amplitude distribution increased in the large amplitude range with decreasing K(IC) values.

AU: NAKAJIMA, S; ARIMA, T
AF: NAKAJIMA, S; ARIMA, T
TI: VIBRATING MECHANISM OF WOODEN STRUCTURES .1. VIBRATING PROPERTIES AND ANALYSIS OF A CONVENTIONAL WALL
DE: FULLSCALE TEST; CONVENTIONAL WALL; DEFORMATION PROPERTY; NATURAL FREQUENCY; VIBRATION MODEL
AB: Full-scale conventional walls were constructed using three different types of connections to connect their vertical and horizontal members. The walls were tested under static and dynamic loads during progressive stages of construction, and the deformation properties of their joints and framing members were clarified. The natural frequencies of the tested walls were estimated by a vibration model based on the deformation properties of the joints and the framing members. The results are summarized as follows: (1) As the rigidity of the joints increased, the displacement of the top of a tested wall decreased. Even using the most rigid connection type, the deformation of the joints was more than 50% of the entire deformation. (2) As the rigidity of the joints increased, the primary natural frequencies increased. (3) Even using the most rigid connection type, the primary natural frequencies of the columns were rather less than those of cantilever beams. The high-degree natural frequencies were quite similer to those of beams supported at both ends. (4) The natural frequencies of the tested wall with joints of little rigidity were estimated properly by a model approximating the frame members as rigid bodies. However, they were over-estimated when the rigidity of the joints became greater.
RP: NAKAJIMA, S (reprint author), UNIV TOKYO, FAC AGR, TOKYO 113, JAPAN.
PA: 1-1-17, MUKOGAOKA, BUNKYO-KU, TOKYO, 113-0023, JAPAN

AU: NAKAJIMA, S; ARIMA, T
AF: NAKAJIMA, S; ARIMA, T
TI: VIBRATING MECHANISM OF WOODEN STRUCTURES .2. VIBRATING ANALYSIS BASED ON A SEMIRIGID FRAME MODEL OF A CONVENTIONAL WALL
DE: FULL-SCALE CONVENTIONAL WALL; DYNAMIC PROPERTY; NATURAL FREQUENCY; JOINT; SEMIRIGID FRAME
AB: Full-scale conventional walls were tested under static and dynamic loads during progressive stages of construction. The dynamic properties of the tested walls and the deformation properties of their joints were clarified. The natural frequencies of the tested walls were estimated by a vibration model in which the walls were considered as semi-rigid frames. Comparing the experimentally measured values with the estimated values, the adequacy of the model was verified. The results are summarized as follows: (1) A conventional frame wall can be treated as an semi-rigid frame whose framing members are connected by rotational and elastic springs. (2) The modulus of rotational limpness of the joints of the columns were calculated from the results of the static loading test. The calculated modulus generally decreased as the rigidity of the joints increased and increased as the displacement of the top of the column increased. (3) The modulus of elastic limpness of the ends of the braces also were calculated from the results of the static loading test. The modulus of the tension braces generally increased as the displacement of the top of the wall increased. On the other hand, the modulus of the compression braces converged to a certain value. (4) The values of the moduli of elastic limpness of the tension braces exceeded the values of the compression braces. (5) The natural frequencies of the tested structures were estimated adequately by performing an eigenvalue analysis on a semi-rigid frame model.
RP: NAKAJIMA, S (reprint author), UNIV TOKYO, FAC AGR, TOKYO 113, JAPAN.
PA: 1-1-17, MUKOGAOKA, BUNKYO-KU, TOKYO, 113-0023, JAPAN

AU: SHIDA, S; SATOH, M; ARIMA, T
AF: SHIDA, S; SATOH, M; ARIMA, T
TI: UTILIZATION AND EVALUATION OF EXTERIOR WOOD .1. RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN METEOROLOGICAL ELEMENTS AND SURFACE TEMPERATURES OF WOOD DECK
DE: THERMAL PERFORMANCE; EXTERIOR WOOD; SURFACE TEMPERATURE; SOLAR RADIATION; MULTIPLE REGRESSION ANALYSIS
AB: The surface temperature of a wood deck made of SPF (spruce-pine-fir) 2" x 4" members was measured under exterior conditions and the relashonships between the temperature and the meteorological elements were examined by multiple regression analysis. The following results were obtained: (1) The daily mean surface temperature of the deck was affected mainly by meteolorogical elements, namely, global solar radiation, daily mean temperature, and daily minimum temperature. Experimental Equation (3) was obtained for the relationship between the mean surface temperature and the affected meteolorogical elements. (2) The surface temperature of the deck was greater than the air temperature on a clear day, but on a cloudy or a rainy day it was almost the same as the air temperature. (3) The temperature of the deck was less in summer and greater in winter than that of a concrete slab. This result seems to match well with human thermal sensations.

PA: 1-1-17, MUKOGAOKA, BUNKYO-KU, TOKYO, 113-0023, JAPAN

AU: Photinos, DJ; Samulski, ET; Toriumi, H
AF: Photinos, D. J.; Samulski, E. T.; Toriumi, H.
TI: Molecular Ordering in Nematics: The Modular Formulation of the Potential of Mean Torque
ID: LIQUID-CRYSTALS; ALKYL CHAINS; ORIENTATIONAL ORDER; DIPOLAR COUPLINGS; FIELD; 4-NORMAL-ALKYL-4-CYANOBIPHENYLS; FLEXIBILITY
AB: The general framework for the description of orientational ordering of (flexible) molecules in the nematic phase in terms of ordering properties of submolecular units in a modular fashion is presented. Various choices of the elementary submolecular units (segments) leading to different representations of the potential of mean torque are discussed. Transformations among such representations are studied in order to clarify the physical significance of intersegmental correlation terms. It is shown that for n-alkane solutes and chains pendant to nematogenic cores in neat materials, the uncorrelated bond representation (each C-C bond segment individually interacts with the nematic mean field) used in most of the previous studies of this type gives a poor description of chain ordering. The introduction of orientational correlations among bond segments (particularly nearest neighbor correlations) improves the quality of fits of the order parameter profiles and explains the difficiency of previous models. The NMR data are described accurately by a representation wherein the potential is additive with respect to slightly biaxial CH, (CH,) "atom-blocks." When the biaxiality of the blocks is neglected one obtains a potential which is additive with respect to the chord segments (i.e. segments joining the mid points of adjacent C-C bonds) which also gives fairly accurate results. The results indicate that the ordering of the chain is driven essentially by the alignment of individual chord segments, an ordering mechanism that is consistent with excluded volume considerations.

TI: VIRULENCE-ASSOCIATED CHROMOSOMAL LOCI OF SHIGELLA-FLEXNERI IDENTIFIED BY RANDOM TN5 INSERTION MUTAGENESIS
ID: ESCHERICHIA-COLI K-12; EVOKE KERATOCONJUNCTIVITIS; NUCLEOTIDE-SEQUENCE; GEL-ELECTROPHORESIS; MOLECULAR-CLONING; LARGE PLASMID; HELA-CELLS; INVASION; ANTIGENS; GENES
AB: Shigellae are the causative agents of bacillary dysentery and are capable of invading epithelial cells, multiplying therein and spreading into adjacent cells. To identify genes on the chromosome associated with the virulence phenotype, 9114 independent Tn5 insertion mutants were isolated in a virulent strain of Shigella flexneri. By using an in vitro assay for intercellular spread or an animal infection model, the Sereny test, 50 chromosomal Tn5 mutants with reduced virulence were identified. The 50 mutants were characterized with respect to their virulence phenotypes, including three different mutations that affect invasion of epithelial cells, bacterial metabolism and structure of lipopolysaccharide. Mutants with reduced invasive ability were further characterized and it was found that two of them had decreased levels of IpaB, C and D antigens as well as the mRNA for the ipaBCD operon encoded by the large virulence plasmid, suggesting that positive regulatory elements for the ipaBCD operon are encoded by the chromosome. Assignment of the 50 Tn5 insertions of the mutants to the 19 Notl restriction fragments of the chromosomal DNA has permitted the identification of at least nine virulence-associated chromosomal loci.

TI: FLUCTUATIONS IN POTENTIAL AND DYNAMICS OF MOLECULES IN LIQUIDS
DE: Molecular dynamics; far-infrared spectroscopy; liquid carbon dioxide
AB: Results from molecular dynamics of liquid argon and far-infrared spectroscopy of liquid carbon dioxide are compared with those based on a model of a harmonic oscillator undergoing Brownian motion with fluctuations in the spring constant. It is found that both data are fitted well when the friction constant is set zero, indicating that the irreversibility of dynamical behaviour of the liquids arises from fluctuations in potential rather than collisions.

AU: Tsuneyuki, S; Aoki, H; Matsui, Y
AF: Tsuneyuki, Shinji; Aoki, Hideo; Matsui, Yoshito
TI: PRESSURE-INDUCED STRUCTURAL TRANSFORMATIONS IN FRAMEWORK CRYSTAL STRUCTURES: A MOLECULAR DYNAMICS STUDY OF SILICA
DE: Silica; structural transformation; high-pressure; diffusion
AB: Pressure-induced structural transformation of polymorphs of silica (SiO2) at room temperature is studied with the molecular dynamics method. Novel structural transitions are predicted in which the tetrahedral coordination of silicon to oxygen collectively collapses into an octahedral coordination without breaking any Si-O bonds. The relation between such transformations and the atomic diffusion in the liquid phase is briefly discussed.

AU: Kaneko, T; Yamamoto, R
AF: Kaneko, T.; Yamamoto, R.
TI: MONTE-CARLO SIMULATIONS OF THE GROWTH OF THIN METAL FILMS AND OSCILLATION OF SURFACE STEP DENSITY
DE: Crystal growth; RHEED intensity oscillation; surface step density
AB: The growth of metal films was simulated with two models of surface diffusion and the relationships between the evolution of surface step densites and growth condition were investigated. In one case, we modeled thermally activated surface migration by the Arrhenius relation. When nickel grew above 430 K at substrate temperature, clear periodic oscillations of the number of steps on the surface were observed. In the other case, epitaxial growth at 0K was simulated in which we modeled that deposited atoms can move by the hopping employed by the kinetic energy of the evaporated atom. The step density can oscillate with one monolayer growth period when an impinged atom could hop more than 10 times in one direction even at 0K. In the random-hopping-migration model, when the deposited atom can hop more than 28 times, the step density oscillation can be obtained.

AU: Sasajima, Y; Suzuki, K; Ozawa, S; Yamamoto, R
AF: Sasajima, Yasushi; Suzuki, Koichi; Ozawa, Satoru; Yamamoto, Ryoichi
TI: MOLECULAR DYNAMICS STUDY OF THE THIN FILM FORMATION PROCESS
DE: Thin film formation; molecular dynamics; growth mode; depth of potential; substrate temperature
AB: The initial stage of thin film formation process was studied by the molecular dynamics method. The Morse function was assumed as the interaction potential between the substrate-substrate, substrate-deposited and deposited-deposited atoms. The interfacial structure of the calculated system was restricted to be coherent, i.e. the structures of the substrate and the deposited atoms were both fcc and had the same lattice constants. The depth of the potentials for the three types of interaction was changed to study its effects on the film structure. The substrate temperature was also varied to see the temperature dependence of the relaxation process of the film structure. Two kinds of structure of the deposited films were considered; three atomic layers of fcc( 111) and a monolayer of fcc(111). Both consisted of 19 atoms. They were considered as the nucleus of the film at the initial stage of the deposition process. The deposited nuclei were relaxed into equilibrium shapes such as the monolayer, the 3 dimensional island and the intermediate structure, which were determined by the ratios of the depths of the potentials for the deposited-deposited atoms D-ff and the deposited-substrate atoms D-fs. The relaxed structures were dependent upon the initial structure, but roughly speaking, D-ff/D-fs > 2 made the 3 dimensional island structure, D-ff/D-fs < 1 produced a monolayer and 1 < D-ff/D-fs < 2 the intermediate structure. The appropriate substrate temperature was necessary to accomplish such structural transitions. A low substrate temperature kept the film in the initial structure.

TI: GENOTOXICITY AND CELL PROLIFERATIVE ACTIVITY OF OMEPRAZOLE IN RAT STOMACH MUCOSA
DE: OMEPRAZOLE; UNSCHEDULED DNA SYNTHESIS; ORNITHINE DECARBOXYLASE; RAT STOMACH
ID: UNSCHEDULED DNA-SYNTHESIS; ORNITHINE DECARBOXYLASE; CARCINOGENS; INDUCTION; SECRETION
AB: Induction of unscheduled DNA synthesis (UDS) as a marker of genotoxicity and induction of ornithine decarboxylase (ODC) activity as a marker of cell proliferative activity by omeprazole were determined in the glandular stomach mucosa of male F344 rats after oral administration. Commercial enteric-coated omeprazole (Losec) at doses of 30 and 100 mg/kg body weight induced a dose-dependent increase in UDS but not replicative DNA synthesis in the pyloric mucosa of rat stomach 4 h after its administration. Dose-dependent significant induction of ODC activity was observed in fundic and pyloric mucosa with a maximum 8 h after administration of omeprazole at doses of 37.5-100 mg/kg body weight. These results show that omeprazole has genotoxicity and cell proliferative activity in the rat glandular stomach mucosa.

AF: MISHINA, Y; AYUSAWA, D; SENO, T; KOYAMA, H
TI: THYMIDYLATE STRESS INDUCES HOMOLOGOUS RECOMBINATION ACTIVITY IN MAMMALIAN-CELLS
DE: HOMOLOGOUS RECOMBINATION; THYMIDYLATE STRESS; MAMMALIAN CELL; FLUORODEOXYURIDINE; GENE TARGETING
ID: MOUSE FM3A CELLS; SYNTHASE-NEGATIVE MUTANTS; DOUBLE-STRAND BREAKS; DNA-SEQUENCES; INDUCTION; EXTRACTS; DEATH; YEAST
AB: We studied whether homologous recombination activity in mammalian cells could be induced by thymidylate stress (thymidylate deprivation). In vitro recombination activity in cell extracts was measured with pSV2neo-derived plasmids. When prior to the preparation of extracts, mouse FM3A cells were grown in 5-fluorodeoxyuridine (FdUrd), an inducer of thymidylate stress, the homologous recombination activity was significantly induced, as judged from an increase in the number of neomycin-resistant bacterial colonies. Maximum induction was observed in cells treated with 1-mu-M FUdR for 16 h. However, 3-8 h of treatment of FM3A cells with the drug followed by an additional 8-16-h incubation in its absence was sufficient to induce the recombination activity while slightly reducing their growth rates. These results indicate that thymidylate stress induces homologous recombination activity in mammalian cells as observed in Escherichia coli and in yeast.

TI: ENDOSCOPIC MANAGEMENT OF SHOULDER PAIN IN LONG-TERM HEMODIALYSIS-PATIENTS
DE: AMYLOID; BETA2-MICROGLOBULIN; ENDOSCOPIC SURGERY; HEMODIALYSIS; SHOULDER PAIN
ID: CHRONIC-HEMODIALYSIS
AB: In 48 shoulders of 29 patients receiving long-term haemodialysis and complaining of intolerable shoulder pain, endoscopic resection of the coracoacromial ligament was performed under local anaesthesia on an outpatient basis, using the Universal Subcutaneous Endoscope system. Predominant endoscopic findings were proliferation of the subacromial bursae and popping between the coracoacromial ligament and the rotator cuff. Amyloid originating from beta-2 microglobulin (beta-2-M) was demonstrated in 87% of the resected coracoacromial ligaments and 86% of the subacromial bursae. Resection of the coracoacromial ligament relieved the shoulder pain in all patients.

AU: UTSUGI, A; ISHIKAWA, M
AF: UTSUGI, A; ISHIKAWA, M
TI: CONSTRUCTION OF INNER SPACE REPRESENTATION OF LATTICED NETWORK CIRCUITS BY LEARNING
DE: PARALLEL SENSOR; ANALOG RESISTIVE CIRCUIT
ID: COMPUTATIONAL VISION; POSED PROBLEMS
AB: A position-detective sensor with an intrinsic inner coordinate system using a parallel calculation schema is proposed. The schema keeps the calculation time dependent of the resolution or the size. Because the inner coordinates are defined as a representation that is suited to the usage of the sensor, they are different from the physical coordinates, which are provided by the arrangement of the detectors. The architecture has a latticed resistive network circuit that can detect moments of input distribution by using its boundary currents. The position of an object to be measured is acquired as an analog value by the circuit. This circuit retains inner coordinates in the resistance distribution. In addition, it is shown that the inner coordinates can be obtained by the adaptive modification of the resistance distribution. Finally, the construction of a position-detective sensor with a non-uniform detector arrangement is simulated and the validity of the method confirmed.

AU: AMARI, S
AF: AMARI, S
TI: DUALISTIC GEOMETRY OF THE MANIFOLD OF HIGHER-ORDER NEURONS
DE: AFFINE CONNECTION; APPROXIMATION; DIFFERENTIAL GEOMETRY; DUAL GEOMETRY; HIGHER-ORDER NEURONS; NEURAL MANIFOLDS; PROJECTION; RIEMANNIAN METRIC
ID: DIFFERENTIAL GEOMETRY; INFERENCE
AB: A set of neural networks, in particular the set of all the neurons of higher-order, forms a geometrical manifold. Specifically, the sets N(k)(k = 1,2,...) of the kth order neurons constitute a hierarchy of manifolds N(n) superset-of N(n-1) superset-of ... superset-of N1, where n is the number of inputs. A natural geometry is introduced to N(k) and characteristics of higher-order neurons are studied therefrom. A Riemannian metric is defined in N(k) and a dual pair of affine connections are introduced in these manifolds. A higher-order neuron realizes a transformation from vector inputs to a scalar output. Given a transformation, the approximation problem searches for its best approximation by a higher-order neuron. The best approximation is proved to be obtained by the dual geodesic projection (Projection Theorem). Moreover, the approximation error is decomposed into a sum of contributions corresponding to various orders of higher-order interactions (Decomposition Theorem). The accuracy of statistical estimation is also shown in terms of the dimensionality of a model and the number of examples (Estimation Theorem). This paper proposes an information geometrical method, which can be applied to more general neural network manifolds.

AU: KUWAKI, T; KOSHIYA, N; TERUI, N; KUMADA, M
AF: KUWAKI, T; KOSHIYA, N; TERUI, N; KUMADA, M
TI: ENDOTHELIN-1 MODULATES CARDIORESPIRATORY CONTROL BY THE CENTRAL-NERVOUS-SYSTEM
CT: SATELLITE SYMP ON CHEMISTRY AND BIOLOGY OF ENDOTHELIN
SP: INT UNION PHARM
ID: BINDING-SITES; RAT-BRAIN; LOCALIZATION; SURFACE
AB: In urethane-anesthetized, vagotomized and immobilized rats under artificial ventilation, an intracisternal injection of 0.1 pmol of endothelin-1 resulted in immediate increases, lasting for 3-15 min, in arterial pressure, heart rate and renal sympathetic nerve activity. Phrenic nerve activity and the rate of its burst activity (burst rate) also increased initially but subsequently decreased for 5-20 min. At doses of 1 or 10 pmol, the initial increases (phase I) were followed by a period of decreases in all variables, that lasted for 20-80 min, below the pre-injection level (phase II). Phrenic nerve activity often disappeared completely. All the variables usually returned to, or often exceeded, pre-injection levels (phase III). However, arterial pressure sometimes remained below control for at least 2 h. Topical application of endothelin-1 to the ventral surface of the medulla produced the same pattern of changes as with intracisternal injection. This particular response pattern was not generated by local administration to any other brain sites examined. In conclusion, intracisternally administered endothelin-1 modulates cardiorespiratory control by the central nervous system. The effect on the central respiratory control was especially powerful. The ventral surface of the medulla appears to play a crucial role in this modulation.

ID: MICROTUBULE-ASSOCIATED PROTEINS; CENTRAL NERVOUS-SYSTEM; MOLECULAR-STRUCTURE; DIFFERENTIAL EXPRESSION; ALZHEIMERS-DISEASE; QUICK-FREEZE; MOUSE-BRAIN; PC12 CELLS; BINDING; NEURONS
AB: A microtubule-associated protein, tau, promotes microtubule assembly, forms characteristic short cross-bridges (< 20 nm) between microtubules, and switches isoforms from juvenile to adult at the end of the first postnatal week in the rat brain. The developmental expression of tau was studied in rat central nervous system, mainly the cerebrum and cerebellum, by in situ hybridization. Tau mRNAs were localized in a wide variety of neural cells. The expression of tau mRNAs in the spinal cord appeared to precede that in the brain, and the expression in the brainstem appeared to precede that in the cerebral cortex and cerebellum. On neural cells throughout the cortical plate of the cerebral cortex, tau mRNAs were expressed in large amounts during the first postnatal week, but by the third postnatal week the expression had become reduced. In the cerebellum, tau mRNAs were enriched in granule cells. The expression in the internal granular layer peaked during the second and third postnatal weeks, and the relatively high level of expression persisted to young adulthood. Thin section transmission electron microscopic study revealed that the proportion of neighboring microtubules in parallel fiber axons of cerebellar granule cells with the distance < 20 nm was as low as 10% at the end of the first postnatal week, but this proportion increased to as high as 35% at the end of the second postnatal week. Northern blot analysis showed that tau mRNAs were congruent-to 6 kb as was reported previously, and those detected in the first postnatal week were three- to five-fold more abundant and approximately 0.2 kb smaller than those detected in the second or third postnatal weeks. The data suggest that (a) tau mRNAs are abundantly expressed in a wide variety of neurons in the central nervous system at the stage of neurite formation, and (b) tau mRNAs are expressed in more basal levels at later stages, but may be important in the formation and maintenance of characteristic microtubule bundles typically found in parallel fiber axons and in other axons.

AU: SATOH, H; NIMURA, Y
AF: SATOH, H; NIMURA, Y
TI: GROWTH PROMOTION IN JAPANESE EEL BY THE ORAL-ADMINISTRATION OF AN ESTROGEN (DIETHYLSTILBESTROL)
ID: SEX REVERSAL; ONCORHYNCHUS-KISUTCH; SALMONID CULTURE; COHO SALMON; 17-ALPHA-METHYLTESTOSTERONE
AB: Oral administration of an estrogen, sodium diethylstilbestrol (DES-Na) was found to promote the growth in Japanese eel elvers when DES-Na was mixed with the basal feed at the level of 0.5-1.0 ppm; the higher the dose, the faster the growth. However, it retarded the growth when applied at the levels above 2.5 ppm. The elvers of 0.3 g grew to 22-28 g within 104 days at the temperature of 23.0-25.5-degrees-C when they fed on the feed having 1.0 ppm DES-Na; the final body weight was 2.7 times of that of control group. Including the control group, the specific daily growth rate in body weight ranged 0.033-0.044. The feed efficiency was 12-19% in terms of wet weight. Since the maintenance ration during the experimental period did not changed in spite of different mean body weight, DES-Na is thought to save the maintenance cost under the optimal application.

TI: ACCUMULATION OF PARALYTIC SHELLFISH TOXINS BY GREEN MUSSEL PERNA-VIRIDIS BY FEEDING ON CULTURED-CELLS OF ALEXANDRIUM-COHORTICULA ISOLATED FROM THE GULF OF THAILAND
ID: PROTOGONYAULAX-TAMARENSIS; DINOFLAGELLATE
AB: Twelve clones of Alexandrium cohorticula were newly isolated from the Gulf of Thailand and made cultured. All the clones were found to be toxic. However, the toxicity levels per cell were different from clone to clove even when cultured under the same conditions. The green mussel Perna viridis which were fed on the cultured cells of A. cohorticula accumulated about 50% of the toxin contained in the supplied cells, showing that A. cohorticula may cause bivalve toxicity, when it blooms in the environment.

AU: IWAMOTO, M; YAMANAKA, H; WATABE, S; HASHIMOTO, K
AF: IWAMOTO, M; YAMANAKA, H; WATABE, S; HASHIMOTO, K
TI: CHANGES IN ATP AND RELATED BREAKDOWN COMPOUNDS IN THE ADDUCTOR MUSCLE OF ITAYAGAI SCALLOP PECTEN-ALBICANS DURING STORAGE AT VARIOUS TEMPERATURES
ID: RIGOR-MORTIS
AB: Striated adductor muscle samples (11.6 g on average) of "itayagai" scallop Pecten albicans were stored at -3, 0, 5, and 10-degrees-C, and examined for changes in ATP and related breakdown compounds. After 6 h of storage at -3 and 0-degrees-C, ATP disappeared and ADP decreased down to 10% in its molar ratio to the total of ATP and related compounds. At 5 and 10-degrees-C, ATP and ADP decreased more slowly, maintaining the levels of 7-13% and 21-29%, respectively, even after 48 h. These degradation patterns of ATP at different temperatures as a whole, resembled those reported for fish. On the other hand, K value, a freshness indicator defined as the molar ratio of inosine plus hypoxanthine to the total of ATP and related compounds, increased faster at -3 and 0-degrees-C than at 5 and 10-degrees-C. However, the adductor muscle resulted in the worst organoleptic evaluation when stored at 10-degrees-C. When unshucked itayagai scallop was stored at 5-degrees-C, adductor muscle ATP remained at a high level (approximately 4 mu-mol/g) for a few days, then sharply decreased probably in association with death, as did the isolated adductor.

AF: PARK, CK; MATSUI, T; WATANABE, K; YAMAGUCHI, K; KONOSU, S
TI: EXTRACTIVE NITROGENOUS CONSTITUENTS OF 2 SPECIES OF EDIBLE ASCIDIANS STYELA-CLAVA AND S PLICATA
AB: The muscles of two species of edible ascidians Styela clava and S. plicata cultured at the south coast of Korea, were analyzed for extractive nitrogen, free and combined amino acids, nucleotides and related compounds, quatenary ammonium bases, and guanidino compounds using specimens collected in December, 1988 and April, 1989, and compared with those of Halocynthia roretzi already reported. Taurine, proline, glutamic acid, glycine, and alanine were the major free amino acids in each sample. Among them, taurine was the most abundant, occupying 43-65% of total free amino acids. The content of glycinebetaine was also high in the April samples, being more than 300 mg per 100 g. As for nucleotides and related compounds, AMP was the principal constituent in all the samples. The composition of the major extractive components such as free amino acids, nucleotides and related compounds, and betaines in the muscles of both species was similar to that of H. roretzi, and many of those components seemed to exhibit the same seasonal variation, low in winter and high in spring, as observed for H. roretzi. The tunic of S. plicata was very poor in extractive components, but the amounts of combined amino acids were considerably higher than those in the muscle.

TI: ANOMALOUS ION HEATING IN REPUTE-1 ULTRA-LOW Q AND REVERSED FIELD PINCH PLASMAS
ID: CONFINEMENT; TRANSPORT; DISCHARGE; DENSITY
AB: Measurements of ion and electron temperatures on REPUTE-1 ultra-low q (ULQ) and reversed field pinch (RFP) plasmas have revealed that the ion temperature is higher than the electron temperature and that the impurity ion temperature exceeds the hydrogen ion temperature. In ULQ plasmas the impurity ion temperature is correlated with the amplitude of the magnetic field fluctuations observed outside the plasma. A model on ion heating by fluctuations is found to explain the experimental results.

TI: PHOTODIODE SENSED SCINTILLATION-COUNTER FOR DETECTION OF A LARGE NUMBER OF CASCADE SHOWER ELECTRONS
SO: NUCLEAR INSTRUMENTS & METHODS IN PHYSICS RESEARCH SECTION A-ACCELERATORS SPECTROMETERS DETECTORS AND ASSOCIATED EQUIPMENT
ID: EXTENSIVE AIR SHOWERS; GAMMA-RAY FAMILIES
AB: A scintillation counter equipped with a PIN silicon photodiode has been developed for the detection of high density electrons of cascade showers which are induced by high energy cosmic rays. This counter, being placed under an iron absorber of 14.5 r.l. in thickness, was tested at Mt. Norikura to detect high energy gamma-ray and hadron induced bursts. The minimum detectable number of shower electrons is found to be about 1.5 x 10(3) per unit detector of area 0.25 m2. This lower bound is corresponding to the number of electrons induced by a vertically incident gamma-ray with an energy of 0.8 TeV.

TI: SYNTHESIS OF FUSED OLIGORIBONUCLEOTIDES WITH TRIDEOXYRIBONUCLEOTIDE CONTAINING PHOSPHOROTHIOATE TO STABILIZE AGAINST NUCLEASE ACTIVITY
ID: HUMAN IMMUNODEFICIENCY VIRUS; RNA; PHOSPHOTRIESTER; REPLICATION; OLIGODEOXYNUCLEOTIDES; DERIVATIVES; INHIBITION; ANALOGS
AB: Fused oligonucleotides(21mer) consisting of RNA(18mer) and DNA(3mer) were synthesized by combined use of the phosphotriester and phosphoramidite methods. The RNA(18mer) corresponds to the leader sequence of phage f1 coat protein mRNA containing initiation codon. The RNA was stabilized against 3'-exonucleases by joining with trideoxy-ribonucleotides containing phosphorothioate linkages and it would be applied to the studies on the initiation complex formation in prokaryotic translation.
